clinical_study.brief_title: Practice With Simulator Improves Basic ERCP Skills of Surgical Trainees
clinical_study.official_title: Practice With ERCP Mechanical Simulator (EMS) Improves Basic ERCP Skills of Novice Surgical Trainees

lead_sponsor.agency: Hepatopancreatobiliary Surgery Institute of Gansu Province

clinical_study.source: Hepatopancreatobiliary Surgery Institute of Gansu Province

brief_summary.textblock: To test the benefits of ERCP Mechanical Simulator (EMS) practice in improving ERCP cannulation success rate of novice surgical trainees.

detailed_description.textblock: Practicing Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) procedures using the EMS provides opportunities for novice endoscopists to learn basic ERCP skills without a patient. In two randomized controlled trials (RCT), coached EMS practice increased selective bile duct cannulation success rate of novice endoscopists. Surgical trainees do not have sufficient endoscopy experience to meet the perceived basic requirement for ERCP training. However, ERCP is done with a side-viewing scope and even experienced GI trainees have difficult initially mastering the basic skill with scope manipulation and cannulation. It is not known whether EMS can provide additional benefit to novice surgical ERCP trainees.

primary_outcome.measure: Success rate of bile duct cannulation
primary_outcome.description: Trainees received verbal instructions, hands-on assistance from the trainer no more than three times in performing the clinical procedure. The trainer took over if the trainee still failed after 20 minutes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Successful cannulation time from first achieve the papilla

secondary_outcome.description: The ability of trainees to perform solo diagnostic biliary cannulation and deep cannulation
Subjective competency graded by supervising physicians as above average, average or below average based on objective criteria.

arm_group.description: Device: ERCP mechanical simulator training EMS group was coached (by JWL) on how to use the EMS, and then practiced with supervision by a senior surgeon biliary endoscopist (WBM). Trainees practiced for a total of 20 hours performing basic maneuvers including scope insertion 2 hours, scope positioning 6 hours, selective guide wire cannulation of common bile duct (CBD) stricture or pancreatic duct (PD) 10 hours and placement of a biliary stent 2 hours. All trainees received hands-on supervised clinical ERCP practice on patients. Time taken to perform ERCP procedures was documented. Trainees received verbal instructions, hands-on assistance from the trainer in performing the clinical procedure. If the trainee still failed after 20 minutes, the trainer took over.

Other: Routine ERCP training group All trainees received hands-on supervised clinical ERCP practice on patients. Time taken to perform ERCP procedures was documented. Trainees received verbal instructions, hands-on assistance from the trainer in performing the clinical procedure. If the trainee still failed after 20 minutes, the trainer took over.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- No experienced surgical trainees receiving ERCP training
Exclusion Criteria:
- Experienced surgical ERCP trainees or who are not receiving ERCP training
